Nonabelian Hodge theory, redux

Jul 18, 2020

In this post, I would like to discuss nonabelian Hodge theory in characteristic , and the possibility of homotopifying it. Unlike in characteristic zero, the correspondence here is entirely in the algebraic world. Let’s begin by discussing the classical results of Ogus and Vologodsky. Let be a smooth -algebra over a perfect field , and let be a flat lift of to with a lift of the Frobenius on . Let be a scheme over , along with a lift of to . Suppose, further, that the relative Frobenius over lifts to .

Then, Ogus and Vologodsky prove that there is an equivalence between the category of modules on with a flat connection and modules over with a Higgs field . The correspondence goes as follows.

  • Suppose is a module with a Higgs field over . The lift defines the Deligne-Illusie lift of the Cartier map, given by . The bundle over is then given by , and . Here, is the canonical Frobenius descent connection on .
  • Suppose is a module with flat connection over . Let denote the -curvature of ; this can be regarded as a map . Then, the connection has zero -curvature, and so by Cartier/Frobenius descent, the pair descends a bundle to . The Higgs bundle associated to is then .

We would like to understand this from the point of view of Hochschild homology. To begin with, suppose is of characteristic zero and is a smooth -scheme. Then, it was shown here that there is an equivalence of categories between and (this means a 2-periodic version of right D-modules). The proof of this result relies on two important non-formal statements: the formality of Hochschild homology in characteristic zero (which is related to the formality of ), and the Atiyah-Bott localization theorem.

Now, Preygel’s result can be refined a bit. Namely (again, is of characteristic zero), the equivalence refines to a filtered equivalence which keeps track of the Hodge filtration. Namely, there is an equivalence . Then, there is an equivalence between filtered coherent -modules and filtered coherent modules over (where this filtration comes from the -homotopy fixed points spectral sequence, so ). Taking the associated graded of this gives a -linear equivalence between -modules and -modules.

Preygel’s result is false in characteristic , because Hochschild homology is not formal. However, there is an analogue of this result, which can be stated as follows. Recall that admits a filtration whose th associated graded is . Negative cyclic homology is categorified by . This category admits an filtration, which comes from the filtered circle introduced here. Note that this category is -linear. Then, the analogue of Preygel’s result is the statement that the associated graded of this category is equivalent to as -linear categories. (Here, is the sheaf of crystalline differential operators.) We write this as . Just as in characteristic zero, there is a -linear equivalence between -modules and -modules.

So, from this point of view, the Ogus-Vologodsky equivalence can be ``two-periodified’’ to a -linear equivalence between (note that there is an equivalence ) and . It’s clear from phrasing this way that what we should be doing, in the case when is affine (say ), at least, is looking for a Cartier isomorphism compatible with the filtrations on both sides. This was proved here by Kaledin.

To make this homotopical, we would want a homotopical analogue of this statement (as well as the categorification, but let’s set our sights on a simpler goal for now). Namely, if is an -linear stable -category which lifts to (and satisfies some additional condition), we would like an equivalence . This is a generalization of Kaledin’s result to the categorical setting, but I don’t know how to prove it. By Proposition 2.15 here, there is a Frobenius linear equivalence , where is the degree generator of . So, we are reduced to showing that there is a (linear) equivalence for certain . More generally, we can ask for an equivalence between and for certain dualizable -modules in cyclotomic spectra.

I’m purposely being a little ambiguous here: I haven’t said exactly what means, but we can interpret it to mean ``Tate construction for the trivial -action on ’’. (What I’d like, for instance, is a relationship between (where acts trivially) and the localization of the free --algebra on a generator in degree , localized at the degree element (i.e., the localization of at the canonical degree element), where is some -ring. I believe the relationship should go as follows. By Proposition 5.4.9 here, the associated graded of the -Tate spectral sequence filtration on can be identified with the graded -algebra in Section 3.4 of Lurie’s paper. Then, there should be a canonical equivalence . If is actually a complex oriented ring, then the -Tate spectral sequence just collapses, and we get . So, in this case, we get an equivalence . This isn’t exactly the thing we wanted in the previous paragraph, but it certainly looks close.)

Anyway, I’m not sure if this is even the right approach to homotopifying the nonabelian Hodge correspondence in characteristic , but it seems interesting nonetheless.

In general, the story above fits into a general paradigm, where the deformation quantization parameter (which appears as the in “-connection”) can be equated with the Bott element . So, the homotopy-theoretic version of a deformation quantization is the datum of an -action. The degeneration of the -adic spectral sequence (i.e., the formality of the deformation quantization problem) is then the degeneration of the -fixed points spectral sequence. Setting (i.e., looking at the associated graded) amounts to killing the Bott element (i.e., looking at the underlying object on which -action), while setting amounts to looking at the -Tate construction. I’ll write about this in more detail later, but I did write a little bit about this perspective in Section 4 here.
